Topic.Title: JS in the Web Editor (Continuing an old thread)

Posts.EditableText: # Continuing this (closed) thread by mrangel: ### http://textadventures.co.uk/forum/quest/topic/e0xah5tpfu6qnzd4v9oscg/javascript-in-web-editor --- ### **THE FUNCTION:** **RunJs** ``` regEx = "//" js = Split(SafeXML(js.description),"<br/>") notes = NewStringList() foreach (line, js) { if (StartsWith(line,"//")) { list add (notes, line) } } js = ListExclude(js,notes) finaljs = NewStringList() foreach (line, js) { code = line if (IsRegExMatch(regEx,line)) { list = Split(line,"//") code = list[0] } list add (finaljs, code) } js = Join(finaljs,"") JS.eval (js) ``` --- NOTE: You can paste that right into code view online. --- I made a room named **js**, then I put this JS in the room description: ``` function testFunct(){ alert('Does this work?'); //Test note } // Test note 2 testFunct(); /** *Test note 3 */ alert('Still working!'); ``` --- --- It works with notes in there now! --- PS This works in the desktop version, too, if you don't like the separate JS files (for whatever reason, like being able to easily email your game to a friend).
Posts.HTML:
Continuing this (closed) thread by mrangel:

http://textadventures.co.uk/forum/quest/topic/e0xah5tpfu6qnzd4v9oscg/javascript-in-web-editor

THE FUNCTION:

RunJs

regEx = "//"
js = Split(SafeXML(js.description),"<br/>")
notes = NewStringList()
foreach (line, js) {
  if (StartsWith(line,"//")) {
    list add (notes, line)
  }
}
js = ListExclude(js,notes)
finaljs = NewStringList()
foreach (line, js) {
  code = line
  if (IsRegExMatch(regEx,line)) {
    list = Split(line,"//")
    code = list[0]
  }
  list add (finaljs, code)
}
js = Join(finaljs,"")
JS.eval (js)

NOTE: You can paste that right into code view online.

I made a room named js, then I put this JS in the room description:

function testFunct(){  
  alert('Does this work?'); //Test note
}
// Test note 2
testFunct();


/**
*Test note 3
*/

alert('Still working!');

It works with notes in there now!

PS

This works in the desktop version, too, if you don't like the separate JS files (for whatever reason, like being able to easily email your game to a friend).

Posts.EditableText:
Okay... 

So can you add a tab to the game object with a new text area that appears when you tick a box on the _Features_ tab. You could put JavaScript in there, and then have the JavaScript automatcally added at the start of your game (in InitInterface, with JS.addScript?).

Then you can call your custom functions with JS. wheneveryou want.
Posts.HTML:
Okay...

So can you add a tab to the game object with a new text area that appears when you tick a box on the Features tab. You could put JavaScript in there, and then have the JavaScript automatcally added at the start of your game (in InitInterface, with JS.addScript?).

Then you can call your custom functions with JS. wheneveryou want.

Posts.EditableText:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30656341/35824111-66068e94-0a77-11e8-9a91-45c409510c97.png)

```
    <tab>
      <caption>Javascript</caption>
      <control>
        <controltype>richtext</controltype>
        <attribute>js_script</attribute>
        <notextprocessor/>
        <expand/>
      </control>
    </tab>
```

---
Oh yeah!

That's the bee's knees!

I didn't know about ```addScript()```.

Right now, I have it calling ```RunGameJs()``` on the very last line of ```StartGame()```.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30656341/35824660-20d98928-0a79-11e8-983f-aaa5ca794ea2.png)

---
As far as I can tell, the attribute doesn't exist until you enter text in that field.

As far as I can tell, the attribute doesn't exist until you enter text in that field.

Help! If I put a ```
``` in that field, Quest replaces it with an actual line break as soon as I click away from the Javascript tab! (It does this in the desktop version or the web editor.) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30656341/35898989-6c1f910e-0b8f-11e8-9dbc-aa04b203dee8.png) --- After clicking on something else then clicking right back on the tab. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30656341/35899002-82769d4e-0b8f-11e8-9c36-0f83552e0855.png) --- PS If I put ```\n``` (like I need to in an alert), it leaves that alone. ```alert("Does this \n work?");``` ...and it works: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30656341/35899063-e7f85a0e-0b8f-11e8-8f89-3370b7d21053.png) --- ...and, when I say, "it works," I mean the whole concept as well as the newline in the alert. (Ha-ha!) The only problem I've come across is Quest turning the ```
``` into an actual line break.
Posts.HTML:
Help!

If I put a <br/> in that field, Quest replaces it with an actual line break as soon as I click away from the Javascript tab!

(It does this in the desktop version or the web editor.)

After clicking on something else then clicking right back on the tab.

PS

If I put \n (like I need to in an alert), it leaves that alone.

alert("Does this \n work?");

...and it works:

...and, when I say, "it works," I mean the whole concept as well as the newline in the alert. (Ha-ha!)

The only problem I've come across is Quest turning the <br/> into an actual line break.

Hrmm...

It's a mystery!

Posts.EditableText:
> I thought it did replace them in room descriptions. As far as I know, all line breaks get converted to `
` in the code, but then all `
` in the code get displayed as line breaks. I think if you type `
` in the description box, it should be converted to `<br/>`. That's why when I was playing around with this originally, I had the script replace `«` with `<` and `»` with `>`; if I want to put HTML within my JS, I can just put «br/» rather than needing to worry about multiple levels of escaping and unescaping. (I use this a lot in quest, because code view in the web version has a horrible habit of mangling HTML in string literals)
Posts.HTML:
I thought it did replace them in room descriptions. As far as I know, all line breaks get converted to <br/> in the code, but then all <br/> in the code get displayed as line breaks.

I think if you type <br/> in the description box, it should be converted to <br/>.
That's why when I was playing around with this originally, I had the script replace « with < and » with >; if I want to put HTML within my JS, I can just put «br/» rather than needing to worry about multiple levels of escaping and unescaping.

(I use this a lot in quest, because code view in the web version has a horrible habit of mangling HTML in string literals)

Posts.EditableText: The ability to copy & paste is a wonderful thing!
Posts.HTML: The ability to copy & paste is a wonderful thing!

This is what I've currently got for the function:

  <function name="RunGameJs">
        <![CDATA[
    if(HasAttribute(game,"js_script")){
      regEx = "//"
      js = Split(SafeXML(game.js_script),"<br/>")
      notes = NewStringList()
      foreach (line, js) {
        if (StartsWith(line,"//")) {
          list add (notes, line)
        }
      }
      js = ListExclude(js,notes)
      finaljs = NewStringList()
      foreach (line, js) {
        code = line
        if (IsRegExMatch(regEx,line)) {
          list = Split(line,"//")
          code = list[0]
        }
        list add (finaljs, code)
      }
      js = Join(finaljs,"")
      js = Replace(js, "[br]", "<br/>")
      js = Replace(js, "[br/]", "<br/>")
      js = Replace(js, "<br/>", "<br/>")
      js = Replace(js, "[break]", "<br/>")
      js = Replace(js, "[linebreak]", "<br/>")
      JS.eval (js)
    }
  ]]></function>

Posts.EditableText: If you haven't got a compose key set up, you could use any convenient symbols; `(=` and `=)` maybe for `<` and `>`, because I don't think there's anywhere they'd be legal in javascript unless they're in a string.
Posts.HTML: If you haven't got a compose key set up, you could use any convenient symbols; (= and =) maybe for < and >, because I don't think there's anywhere they'd be legal in javascript unless they're in a string.

Posts.EditableText:
Oh, I see.  (NOTE TO SELF:  Set up a compose key.)

I just went with a few options the user can use:

```[br]```
```[br/]```
```[break]```
```[linebreak]```

...and I added a note to the tab in the editor to let everyone (including me) know how to work it.
